architectural_notes: Add a top banner area that supports a cropped stock-photo image (license/attribution considerations).
Implement an infinite, slow CSS gloss animation for the main heading text.
Catull is a licensed typeface; use a legally permitted Catull-like substitute (e.g., free web font) for the “older Google logo” feel.
Implement low-res/pixelated look via CSS techniques (filters/rendering settings) without breaking readability/accessibility.
Expand dated-web aesthetic target range to ~2005–2012 (older site structure patterns, YouTube-like layout).
Ensure the low-res treatment specifically evokes a ~480p presentation (coarse imagery/UI treatment) while maintaining usability/readability.
Add an iOS 4 Safari-style scroll indicator/side scroller treatment (visual mimic; ensure usability/accessibility).
Introduce a glassy UI treatment (blur/translucency/highlights) while preserving the retro 2005–2012 YouTube-like layout and readability.
When selecting/randomizing YouTube videos for “moms kitchen”, filter to cooking content and enforce a published-date range of 2011–2026.
Add a subtle early-2000s-style loading spinner (pink-themed) as a nostalgic UI detail; keep it unobtrusive and consistent with the retro portal aesthetic.
known_issues: In the current build, the “moms kitchen” videos and the featured buttons are non-interactive / do nothing.

existing_features.title: Create a single-page joke website whose visible site name is exactly “your_mom’s_website”, including the browser tab title and prominent on-page heading.
Implement a playful homepage layout that clearly reads as a joke site (e.g., punchy tagline, a short paragraph of comedic copy, and a call-to-action button that triggers a harmless joke interaction).
Apply a coherent, distinct visual theme for the site (colors, typography, spacing, and UI styling) and use it consistently across the page; do not use a blue/purple theme.
Add the required generated images to the project under frontend/public/assets/generated and render them on the homepage as part of the visual design.
Update the homepage layout and styling to mimic an early-2010s YouTube UI (nostalgic video-site feel) while keeping the site as a single-page joke experience.
Add a cropped top banner image using a real-looking 2010s-era stock photo of an excited mom giving a thumbs up, and render it at the top of the page as a banner.
Change the main site heading styling so it is creme-colored and has a slow gloss/sheen animation that loops indefinitely.

Update the global color theme to: lighter, vibrant pink page background; darker pink for foreground UI surfaces; white for most text; with an explicit exception that the footer's joke manufacturing text "moms_of_ momland.inc" and the joke copyright notes at the bottom of the page are not white.

Adjust the overall visual treatment to feel intentionally lower-resolution / early-2010s by applying subtle pixelated/low-res styling across the page (while keeping all text readable and the site fully usable).

Update global typography so that all site text uses a Catull-style typeface (use a legally usable free substitute if Catull cannot be embedded), and update the main heading to use a more cartoonish display feel while still fitting the early-2010s aesthetic.

Change the displayed main header text to remove underscores (while keeping the existing browser tab title as “your_mom’s_website”), and animate the header so each letter performs a small cartoonish jump-and-squash loop (or staggered loop) without impacting layout flow.

Add an early-2010s-style sidebar area with small UI boxes that embed mom-themed cooking/baking YouTube videos; the selected videos must be randomized so different visits can show different video selections.

Add an early-2010s-style sidebar area with small UI boxes showing mom-written articles (title + short snippet + source link); the selected articles must be randomized so different visits can show different article selections.

Add a rickroll easter egg: a specific visible word on the page must be clickable and redirect the user to Rick Astley’s “Never Gonna Give You Up” on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ).

Update the homepage layout and UI styling to more strongly reflect common website structures from ~2005–2012 (YouTube-like), emphasizing dated web conventions (e.g., denser page chrome, more boxy modules, stronger borders/dividers, and a more ‘old web portal’ feel) while keeping the app as a single-page joke experience.

Enforce an intentional “480p / low-resolution” presentation across the site so the overall UI feels like it is being viewed in a constrained, older-resolution frame (around 854×480), while keeping all text readable and the site fully usable on modern screens.

Implement an iOS 4 Safari-style scroll indicator (“side scroller”) for the main scrollable area inside the 480p portal frame (the element currently using `overflow-y-auto` in `frontend/src/App.tsx`), so that when the user scrolls, a thin rounded vertical indicator appears near the right edge, tracks scroll position, and fades out after scrolling stops.

Update the portal UI styling to have a glassy iOS-style (glassmorphism) look while preserving the existing pink theme tokens and the 2005–2012 portal layout structure (modules, header, nav, and inset boxes should read as semi-translucent glass surfaces with subtle blur, highlights, and crisp borders).

Update the curated YouTube video list used by the “Mom's Kitchen” sidebar so that it only contains cooking/baking-related videos (not music/songs) and every video in the list is from YouTube and was posted within the year range 2011 through 2026 (inclusive).

Make the currently non-functional UI elements in the header area (including the Upload button, Account button, and the navigation tab buttons like Videos/Featured/Popular) perform a harmless, clearly visible interaction when clicked, and ensure the “Mom's Kitchen” video embeds are actually interactable by the user (playback controls and click interactions work as expected).
Add a subtle, early-2000s-style loading spinner that matches the existing vibrant pink theme and low-res/retro aesthetic, and show it briefly on initial app load within the 480p portal frame.

new_feature_requests.summary: Create a joke website with the name “your_mom’s_website”.
Update UI layout/styling to mimic early-2010s YouTube (nostalgic video-site UI feel).
Add a top-of-page cropped banner using a real stock image of an excited mom giving a thumbs up (2010s-era vibe).
Set heading text color to creme and add a slow, indefinitely looping gloss animation.
Apply new color theme: lighter vibrant pink background, darker pink foreground UI, text in white except footer manufacturing/copyright notes.
Adjust overall visual treatment to feel lower-resolution/early-2010s (e.g., pixelated/low-res styling where appropriate).
Update main header text to remove underscores and use a more cartoonish heading font, with per-letter jump/squash animation.
Switch global site typography to a Catull-style font (use a free substitute if Catull is not legally usable).
Add sidebar UI boxes containing embedded mom-themed cooking/baking YouTube videos that are randomized and change between visits.
Add sidebar UI boxes containing mom-written articles that are randomized and change between visits.
Add a rickroll easter egg: a specific clickable word redirects to Rick Astley’s “Never Gonna Give You Up” on YouTube.
Broaden the retro UI target to mimic older website structures from ~2005–2012 (YouTube-like) and constrain the overall visual presentation to a 480p/low-resolution look.
Add a side scroller/scrollbar visual treatment that mimics iOS 4 Safari.
Update the UI styling to have a glassy (iOS-style/glassmorphism) look.
Constrain “moms kitchen” sidebar video selections to cooking videos (not songs) from YouTube posted within 2011–2026.
Add a subtle early-2000s-style loading spinner (pink-themed) as a throwback detail.
